p:
For hydroxychloroquine sulfate: an open-label, non-randomized clinical trial
18 suggested, compared with the rate of viral nucleic acid turning negative of control group (12.5%), combination of hydroxychloroquine sulfate and azithromycin (100%) and monotherapy of hydroxychloroquine sulfate (57.1%) significantly improved the rate of viral nucleic acid turning negative (P < 0.001). The effect of hydroxychloroquine sulfate is reinforced by azithromycin. And such combination may both act as an antiviral therapy against SARS-CoV-2 and prevent bacterial super-infections. However, a prospective study
19 showed that, for patients with moderate COVID-19, the effect on the rate and the time of viral nucleic acid turning negative were not significant.
